action.action-desc: Mr. Khanna (for himself and Mr. Massie) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend chapter 37 of title 18, United States Code, to authorize appropriate disclosure of classified information, to appropriately limit the scope of the offense of disclosing classified information, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Espionage Act Reform Act of 2022.

section.header: Disclosure of classified information related to signals intelligence

subsection.text: Section 798(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by striking furnishing, and all that follows and inserting the following: “furnishing of information to—

paragraph.text: any Member of the Senate or the House of Representatives;
a Federal court, in accordance with such procedures as the court may establish;

the inspector general of an element of the intelligence community (as defined in section 3 of the National Security Act of 1947 (50 U.S.C. 3003)), including the Inspector General of the Intelligence Community;
the Chairman or a member of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board or any employee of the Board designated by the Board, in accordance with such procedures as the Board may establish;
the Chairman or a commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission or any employee of the Commission designated by the Commission, in accordance with such procedures as the Commission may establish;

the Chairman or a commissioner of the Federal Communications Commission or any employee of the Commission designated by the Commission, in accordance with such procedures as the Commission may establish; or

any other person or entity authorized to receive disclosures containing classified information pursuant to any applicable law, regulation, or executive order regarding the protection of whistleblowers.

subsection.text: Section 798(b) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in the matter preceding the first undesignated paragraph, by striking this section— and inserting this section:;

The term classified information—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (1), as so designated—

subparagraph.text: by inserting and after distribution;; and
by adding at the end the following:

does not include any information that is specifically designated as Unclassified under any Executive Order, Act of Congress, or action by a committee of Congress in accordance with the rules of its House of Congress.

The term unauthorized person means any person who, or agency which, is not authorized to receive information of the categories set forth in subsection (a) of this section by—

subparagraph.text: the President;
the head of a department or agency of the United States Government which is expressly designated by the President to engage in communication intelligence activities for the United States; or

subsection.text: Section 798 of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a), in the matter preceding paragraph (1)—

subparagraph.text: by striking Whoever and inserting Any individual who; and
by inserting obtained by the individual while the individual was a covered person and acting within the scope of his or her activities as a covered person after any classified information; and

paragraph.text: in subsection (b), by inserting after paragraph (3), as so designated and transferred by subsection (b) of this section, the following:
The term covered person means an individual who—

subparagraph.text: receives official access to classified information granted by the United States Government;
signs a nondisclosure agreement with regard to such classified information; and
is authorized to receive information of the categories set forth in subsection (a) of this section—

clause.text: the head of a department or agency of the United States Government which is expressly designated by the President to engage in communication intelligence activities for the United States.

subsection.text: Section 798 of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsection (d) as subsection (e); and
by inserting after subsection (c) the following:
In this subsection, the term foreign agent—

subparagraph.text: has the meaning given the term agent of a foreign power under section 101 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (50 U.S.C. 1801); and

does not include a person who is an agent of a foreign power (as so defined) with respect to a foreign power described in section 101(a)(5) of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (50 U.S.C. 1801(a)(5)).

paragraph.text: A foreign agent who—

subparagraph.text: aids, abets, counsels, commands, induces, or procures the commission of an offense under this section shall be subject to prosecution under this section by virtue of section 2 of this title;

knowing that an offense under this section has been committed by another person, receives, relieves, comforts, or assists such other person in order to hinder or prevent the apprehension, trial, or punishment of such other person shall be subject to prosecution under section 3 of this title;

having knowledge of the actual commission of an offense under this section, conceals and does not as soon as possible make known the same to some judge or other person in civil or military authority under the United States shall be subject to prosecution under section 4 of this title; or
conspires to commit an offense under this section shall be subject to prosecution under section 371 of this title.

paragraph.text: Any person who is not a foreign agent shall not be subject to prosecution under this section by virtue of section 2 of this title or under section 3, 4, or 371 of this title, unless the person—

subparagraph.text: commits a felony under Federal law in the course of committing an offense under this section (by virtue of section 2 of this title) or under section 3, 4, or 371 of this title;
was a covered person at the time of the offense; or
subject to paragraph (4), directly and materially aids, or procures in exchange for anything of monetary value, the commission of an offense under this section with the specific intent to—

clause.text: harm the national security of the United States; or
benefit any foreign government to the detriment of the United States.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (3)(C) shall not apply to direct and material aid that consists of—

subparagraph.text: counseling, education, or other speech activity; or
providing an electronic communication service to the public or a remote computing service (as such terms are defined in section 2510 and 2711, respectively).

section.header: Gathering, transmitting, or losing defense information

subsection.text: Section 793 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: the term covered person means an individual who—

subparagraph.text: receives official access to classified information granted by the United States Government;
signs a nondisclosure agreement with regard to such classified information; and

is authorized to receive documents, writings, code books, signal books, sketches, photographs, photographic negatives, blueprints, plans, maps, models, instruments, appliances, or notes of anything connected with the national defense by—

clause.text: the head of a department or agency of the United States Government which is expressly designated by the President to engage in activities relating to the national defense; and

paragraph.text: the term foreign agent—

subparagraph.text: has the meaning given the term agent of a foreign power under section 101 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (50 U.S.C. 1801); and

does not include a person who is an agent of a foreign power (as so defined) with respect to a foreign power described in section 101(a)(5) of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (50 U.S.C. 1801(a)(5)).

subsection.text: Section 793(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking Whoever and inserting A foreign agent who;
by inserting and with like intent or reason to believe, after aforesaid,; and
by striking he and inserting the foreign agent.

subsection.header: Transmission of lawfully possessed defense information to unauthorized persons
subsection.text: Section 793(d) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by striking or note relating to the national defense, or information relating to the national defense which information and inserting note, or information relating to the national defense, which document, writing, code book, signal book, sketch, photograph, photographic negative, blueprint, plan, map, model, instrument, appliance, note, or information.

subsection.header: Transmission of unlawfully possessed defense information to unauthorized persons
subsection.text: Section 793(e) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to read as follows:

paragraph.text: while a covered person, gains unauthorized possession of, access to, or control over any nonpublic document, writing, code book, signal book, sketch, photograph, photographic negative, blueprint, plan, map, model, instrument, appliance, or note of anything connected with the national defense; and

subparagraph.text: with reason to believe such information could be used to the injury of the United States or to the advantage of any foreign nation, willfully communicates, delivers, transmits, or causes to be communicated, delivered, or transmitted, or attempts to communicate, deliver, transmit, or cause to be communicated, delivered, or transmitted, the same to any person not entitled to receive it; or
willfully—

clause.text: retains the same at an unauthorized location; and
fails to deliver the same to the officer or employee of the United States entitled to receive it; or

section.text: Section 641 of title 18, United States Code, is amended in the first undesignated paragraph by inserting tangible before thing of value.
Nothing in section 793 or 798 of title 18, United States Code, shall be construed to supersede or limit the protections under the speech or debate clause of the Constitution of the United States.
